alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect.

What:
Total snowfall amounts near 10 cm, mainly over areas of higher terrain.
Peak snowfall rates of 2 to 3 cm per hour.
Reduced visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow.

When:
Tapering off this evening.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

alerts.headline: flash freeze warning in effect
alerts.description:
Temperatures are forecast to fall rapidly. Slush and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops.

What:
Water from melting snow is expected to freeze suddenly, especially on untreated surfaces. 

When:
This evening.

Additional information:
A sharp cold front will move through the area. Temperatures are expected to quickly plunge below the freezing mark in the wake of the cold front. Any wet surfaces due to snow melt may become icy and slippery.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas.

alerts.headline: winter storm watch in effect
alerts.description:
Significant snowfall expected.

What:
Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm. The highest amounts are likely over areas of higher terrain.
Reduced visibility in heavy snow.

When:
Sunday morning through Monday.

Additional information:
Snow, heavy at times, is expected with an Alberta clipper later this weekend. There remains some uncertainty with total snowfall accumulations. Winter storm warnings or snowfall warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer.

###

Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

affected_areas.area_description: Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake

alerts.headline: snow squall watch in effect
alerts.description:
Brief, intense snowfall is expected to develop. Under the snow squall, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow.

What:
Near zero visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow.
Peak snowfall rates of 3 to 5 cm per hour.
Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm.

When:
This evening.

Additional Information:
A strong cold front will move northwest to southeast across the area. A brief but intense line of flurries is expected to develop along the cold front. Blowing snow can also occur with strong northerly wind gusts behind the cold front.

###

Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

Snow squall conditions are no longer expected.

alerts.headline: flash freeze warning in effect
alerts.description:
Temperatures are forecast to fall rapidly. Slush and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops.

What:
Water from melting snow is expected to freeze suddenly, especially on untreated surfaces. 

When:
Ending after midnight.

Additional information:
A sharp cold front will move through the area. Temperatures are expected to quickly plunge below the freezing mark in the wake of the cold front. Any wet surfaces due to snow melt may become icy and slippery.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas.

alerts.headline: flash freeze warning in effect
alerts.description:
Temperatures are forecast to fall rapidly. Slush and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops.

What:
Water from melting snow and recent rainfall is expected to freeze suddenly, especially on untreated surfaces. Rain is most likely over the North Bay area before the cold front.

When:
Through early Saturday morning.

Additional information:
A cold front will move through the area tonight. Temperatures are expected to quickly plunge below the freezing mark in the wake of the cold front. Any wet surfaces due to snow melt and rain may become icy and slippery.

###

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas.

Additional information:

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

alerts.headline: snowfall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected.

What:
Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm. The highest amounts are most likely over areas of higher terrain.
Reduced visibility in heavy snow.

When:
Sunday morning through Monday morning.

Additional information:
Snow associated with a passing weather system will begin Sunday morning for areas west of Lake Superior and by early afternoon for areas to the north of the lake. Snowfall amounts will likely be highly variable, with the highest amounts expected over areas of higher terrain. Snow will taper off late Sunday night or early Monday morning.

###

Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

affected_areas.area_description: Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake
Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect for Sunday.

What:
Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm. Higher amounts are possible.
Reduced visibility in areas of heavier snow.

When:
Beginning Sunday morning and ending Sunday night or early Monday morning.

Additional information:
Snow associated with a passing weather system will begin Sunday morning over northwestern Ontario and by early afternoon for areas north of Lake Superior. Snow will taper off from west to east Sunday night into early Monday morning.

Confidence in exact snowfall amounts for this event is low. It is possible that some areas will receive in excess of 15 cm. The area is being monitored for potential snowfall warnings.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.
